Organizer Michael Blair @ 978-808-1932

=====

If you are interested in participating be sure to read the entire event listing before you RSVP - then answer the questions that are part of the RSVP process. While the objective of this event is to enjoy ourselves, your safety, and the safety of the others, is the most important thing. If you underestimate the demands, overestimate your skills and abilities, or come unprepared you may put yourself and/or others at risk – consider this before you decide to participate.

=====

What we're doing

Monica and I will be taking the kayaks out on the Nashua River for an afternoon paddle. The plan is to paddle upstream from the boat launch on Route 111/119 in Groton, MA turning around before reaching the Great Road Bridge in Shirley, MA – we will then follow the same route in reverse to get back to the boat launch.

Guests are not permitted - all participants must be members of the Random Group of Hikers.

=====

Trip Summary

This moderate pace (~ 4 MPH) round-trip paddle will cover about 8 miles and involves paddling along quiet water. I am looking to keep a steady pace with limited stops along the way.

While I have paddled this section of the river many times I have not been there since the recent storms so conditions may have changed. You should do your own research of this trip since you are ultimately responsible for your own safety.

I am not certified or trained in water rescues or first aid. You will need to bring any medications or medical supplies that you may need during the trip.

If you have ANY questions about your ability to participate in and complete this entire event please contact me.

=====

Weather

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.

We will assess travel and weather conditions during the paddle and make changes to our planned trip as necessary.

  • Click here for the current weather forecast for this trip

=====

Clothing and Equipment

Below is a list describing the minimum clothing and equipment required to participate in this event. DO NOT rely on others to share with you once we begin. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this event.

  • Clothing : Dress for the conditions and be prepared for an unexpected flip – wear synthetic clothing that will dry quickly and still provide insulating qualities when wet. Dress in layers to easily regulate body temperatures and bring a fleece jacket/wool sweater, a warm hat, and some gloves. You may want to consider wearing a wet suit or dry suit.
  • Footwear : You should also wear some type of secure footwear (not flip-flops) that will protect your feet when you are in the water and on the shore.
  • Life Jacket : Wear a USGC Type III Personal Flotation Device – this is not an option if you plan to participate. You must WEAR it, not simply bring it along in your boat.
  • Food and Water : High-energy snacks, food for lunch, and enough water to stay properly hydrated during the trip.
  • Other Essential Gear : Plastic whistle (not one with a cork ball since the cork won't work if it's wet) and a compass. Spray skirt appropriate for the type of water we will be paddling on. Bilge Pump (or other bailing device) and Self-Rescue Devices (e.g. paddle float, sling, throw bag). Toilet kit (e.g. hand sanitizer, toilet paper and a zip-lock bag to pack out your used personal hygiene items). Personal first aid kit. Dry clothes for after the event.

=====

Directions

We will begin by meeting at the boat launch on the west side of Route 111/119 in Groton, MA. According to Google Maps this meeting spot is 45 miles from Boston and it should take about 60 minutes to drive there.

  • Click here for driving directions to the meeting spot

=====

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the American Canoe Association’s “Safety Tips for Paddlers” described at www.americancanoe.org ; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
